#Text=Jakob Greber
#Text=Johann Jakob Greber ( ? – buried 5 July 1731 ) was a German Baroque composer and musician .
#Text=His first name sometimes appeared in its Italianized version , Giacomo , especially during the years he spent in London ( 1702 – 1705 ) .
#Text=Greber composed solo cantatas , sonatas , and stage works , including the opera Gli amori di Ergasto which opened London 's Queen 's Theatre in 1705 .
#Text=He died in Mannheim , where for many years he was Kapellmeister of the court orchestra of Charles III Philip , Elector Palatine .
#Text=Life
#Text=Margherita de L'Epine , Greber 's mistress
#Text=during his London years
#Text=Greber 's date and place of birth are unknown , although the Neue Deutsche Biographie proposes an approximate date of 1673 . [ 1 ]
#Text=He is presumed to have studied in Italy and arrived in London from there in 1702 , accompanied by his mistress , the opera singer Margherita de L'Epine .
#Text=He was to remain in London for the next three years composing incidental music for plays and arias for L'Epine .
#Text=In 1703 , Greber composed the incidental music for the premiere of Nicholas Rowe 's play The Fair Penitent , including four arias sung by L'Epine during the interlude .
#Text=It was during this time that Rowe dubbed L'Epine " Greber 's Peg " , a name by which she was known for several years .
#Text=Although L'Epine left Greber in 1703 to live with Daniel Finch , 2nd Earl of Nottingham , she returned to him in 1704 , and they took up residence on Suffolk Street in London .
#Text=He continued composing arias for her and accompanying her in concerts and theatrical interludes at Lincoln 's Inn Fields and other venues . [ 2 ] [ 3 ]
#Text=The London newspaper The Post Man noted their appearance together at the spa town of Tunbridge Wells in August 1703 :

#Text=They write from Tunbridge Wells that there is arrived there that famous Italian Lady , Signiora Francesca Margaretta de L'Epine that gives every week entertainments of musick , all compos 'd by that great Master Signior Jacomo Greber , perform 'd to the content and great satisfaction of all the nobility and gentry . [ 4 ]
#Text=Queen 's Theatre London , where Greber 's Gli amori di Ergasto premiered in 1705
#Text=On 9 April 1705 , the Queen 's Theatre in London was officially opened with Greber 's opera Gli amori di Ergasto ( The Loves of Ergasto ) .
#Text=It was the first opera sung entirely in Italian by Italian singers to be performed in London . [ 5 ]

#Text=The printed libretto also contained an English translation by Peter Anthony Motteux , and on the opening night the performance included a prologue by Samuel Garth and an epilogue by William Congreve , both read by Anne Bracegirdle .
#Text=The opera itself , a pastorale largely consisting of arias and duets between shepherds and nymphs , proved a dismal failure and was only performed a few times . [ 6 ]
#Text=Shortly after the premiere of Gli amori di Ergasto , Greber left London ( without Margherita de L'Epine ) . [ 2 ]
#Text=Greber 's patron Charles Philip

#Text=A baptismal certificate in Düsseldorf , dated 23 June 1705 describes Greber as a Kapellmeister ( music director ) in the service of Charles Philip , [ 1 ] who at the time was the governor of Tyrol with a court in Innsbruck .
#Text=In 1708 Greber married Katharina Elisabeth née von Douven who was probably a relative of Johann Franz von Douven , one of Charles Philip 's treasury officials .
#Text=The couple had at least four children . [ 1 ] [ 7 ]

#Text=Greber remained in the service of Charles Philip for the rest of his career , working closely on operas and other court entertainments with Augustin Stricker , Johann Hugo von Wilderer , and Gottfried Finger ( whom he had known from his London days ) . [ 3 ]
#Text=When Charles Philip succeeded his brother , Johann Wilhelm , as Elector Palatine in 1716 , he combined his brother 's court in Düsseldorf with his own court in Innsbruck .
#Text=The new court was moved first to Neuburg , then to Heidelberg , and finally to Mannheim .
#Text=The Düsseldorf court orchestra was dissolved in the process , but in 1718 , many of its musicians were reinstated in the Innsbruck court orchestra headed by Greber .
#Text=In 1723 , after Charles Philip moved his court to Mannheim , Johann von Wilderer was appointed to serve jointly with Greber as Kapellmeister .
#Text=Wilderer died in 1724 .
#Text=Greber lived on for another seven years , dying in Mannheim in July 1731 .
#Text=The orchestra he led there later became famous as the orchestra of the Mannheim school .
#Text=Works
#Text=Opera and oratorio

#Text=Gli amori di Ergasto ( The Loves of Ergasto ) – pastoral opera in 2 acts ; first performed 9 April 1705 , Queen 's Theatre , London ; revised version performed 1711 , Vienna ; only the score of the Vienna version survives

#Text=L'allegrezza dell'Eno ( The Joy of Eno ) – festa teatrale ; libretto by Giovanni Domenico Pallavicini , overture by Gottfried Finger ; first performed May 1708 , Innsbruck to celebrate the visit of Elisabeth Christine of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel ; score lost
#Text=Enea in Cartagine ( Aeneas in Carthage ) – opera ; first performed 1711 , Komödienhaus , Innsbruck ;
#Text=score lost
#Text=La morte di Cristo ( The Death of Christ ) – oratorio ; first performed 1713 , Innsbruck

#Text=Crudelta consuma amore ( Cruelty Consumes Love ) – pastoral opera in three acts ; pastiche with acts 1 and 3 by composed by Greber , act 2 by Augustin Stricker , and the overture by Gottfried Finger ; first performed 1717 , Neuberg to celebrate the name day of Anna Maria Luisa de ' Medici ; score lost
#Text=Cantatas
#Text=Tu parti idolo mio - alto singer , flute , [ 8 ]
#Text=two violins , and basso continuo
#Text=Quando lungi e il mio fileno - two singers ( soprano and alto ) , two violins and basso continuo
#Text=Filli , tra il gelo e'l foco - soprano singer , two flutes and basso continuo
#Text=Fuori di sua capanna - alto singer , flute and basso continuo
#Text=Chamber music
#Text=Sonata in C major for flute and basso continuo
#Text=Sonata in C minor for two flutes and basso continuo
#Text=Notes and references
